title.rendered: New Logo and Identity for Correios by CDA

content.rendered:
With roots as far back as 1663, the Empresa Brasileira de Correios e Telégrafos (Brazilian Post and Telegraph Corporation) was established in 1969 as the state-owned organization responsible for the national postal service of Brazil. Known simply as Correios, it employs more than 120,000 people distributing over 36 million pieces of mail a day through more than 6,000 locations and with the help of a livery of nearly 20,000. This week, Correios introduced a new logo designed by Brazilian agency CDA.

The new design, the result of a study conducted by the company branding CDA Branding & Design, was born preserving the characteristics already recognized by the public: the colors and arrows – symbolizing the powerful ability to connect people of Posts. The preserves and enhances brand attributes such as trust and commitment, acquired by the Brazilian postal service for over 350 years, while that highlights features of the new phase of the company, such as proximity, flexibility and dynamism.

Correios press release (Google translated)

The previous, abstract arrow logo goes back to 1970, when an architecture student won a contest to design the logo. It’s unclear exactly what it is or means but it communicates movement between two points and, yeah, it has arrows. The typography, last updated in 1990 was fairly comical with the round “E” and drowning “S”. The new logo is an evolution that, probably unintentionally, pays perfect homage to its predecessor: The new icon is some kind of ambiguous arrow/banner shapes and some equally comical typography with a pair of bland “r”s, an “e” with an overbite, and a tittle-less “i”. The icon picks up from the realistic/gradient trend of the early 2000s and the typography picks up the current cut-off trend — neither are good on their own and combined make for an even less appealing result.

Seeing the ads above, I could potentially rally behind the new icon, because it does work quite well when propped, in its full 3D-ness, against other objects, enveloping them in an engaging way. This effect is also well played in the video. You can also see a convincing flat-color version in the retail shot below. It’s not bad. And the retail look also has potential when designed from the ground up. As a band-aid on some run-down locations it just doesn’t quite hold up.

In application there is not much to see yet, other than a lot of yellow and blue and the logo, which would be passable were it not for the unfortunate typography.
